body:
Some investors say that a great team can make a business succeed even if the idea isn't that great. 


On the flip side, a weak team can make a business fail even if the idea is a great one. 


So how can you work out what kind of people your business needs to succeed, and then find those people, convince them to join you and help them to make your business thrive? 


Here's how to:

  • Build a network of experienced mentors and advisers
  • Find and recruit your first employees
  • Understand your legal responsibilities as an employer
title: Here's how

body: What do mentors and advisers bring to your team?

_items.title: What are mentors and advisers?
_items.body:
Mentors are people who support you as an individual on a regular, informal basis. They might give you personal encouragement, talk through key challenges and introduce you to relevant and influential people.


Advisers are a group of supporters with highly relevant skills and experience. They support the organisation as a whole and you might meet 1:1 or as a group. They might give you regular advice or let you use their name to give you credibility.

_items.title: How do you find mentors and advisers?
_items.body:
Be bold! 


Find them through your extended networks of colleagues, friends or family, or by just asking people in the industry who you respect. 


For example, identify people who you think could help with your idea and business, and attend industry events where they might be speaking or taking part. Ask them out for coffee to seek advice and see if they are interested in doing that on a regular basis.


You might use professional networking sites like Linkedin to introduce yourself or make direct contact with people whose articles or blogs you have read. 


On a note of caution,  just because someone has been successful as a middle manager in a major corporation, this may not equip them any better than you for the challenges of a fast-paced start-up!

_items.title: How can you reward them?
_items.body:
More often than not, people who have made it to the top of their field are looking for an opportunity to give back to people and organisations who are just starting out. 


They may well also recognise that down the line, you might become a useful business contact or client for them.


If you are considering giving away equity, make sure that their advice will definitely add value to the business before  rewarding them with equity.  Even a small amount of equity for advice should be, by far, the exception.

title: Mentors and advisers

body:
As you move beyond the founding team, it is a major challenge to find complementary team members who share your passion and purpose, and who are willing to share the challenges of a perilous journey.


Finding the right people can be hard, but thankfully, there is a four step plan to help you along.

_items.title: Step 1 - Write the job description
_items.body:
Plan the role by answering the following questions:

  • What will they need to achieve in the next three years and how will it be measured?
  • What soft skills and technical skills will they need? 
  • What culture are you trying to build in the organisation and what kind of person would fit in?
  • What qualifications do you expect them to have?

_items.title: Step 2 - Look in the right places
_items.body:
Many people find that their personal networks are a great way to find high quality candidates. Social and professional networks like LinkedIn, Facebook, and Twitter can be a great way to get the word out.  


Startup events, co-founder speed dating events and startup job boards like Work in Startups could be a great way to meet candidates.


Show me - Work in Startups

_items.title: Step 3 - Choose the right people
_items.body:
Make sure each candidate speaks to more than one team member. Assess the candidate using a scorecard that lists what you are looking for in a perfect candidate. 


Chemistry is not enough! 


Many organisations find Skype or phone interviews a useful screening method.

Great people are likely to be considering multiple job offers. Expect this to happen.


If you can't entice them with money, fear not.  Think of the other things you can offer. 


For example: mentoring, working with exceptional people, flexibility, high areas of responsibility from the outset, shares in the company, and being part of something important.
_items.title: Step 4 - Sell the role

title: Build your team

body:
There are six legal responsibilities of an employer. 


They are straightforward, but it is very important that you know and act on them all.

_items.title: Decide how much to pay
_items.body:
You must pay your employee at least the national minimum wage. 


It is strongly recommended that you pay at least the London living wage in London of £9.75 per hour, or for regions outside London at £8.45 per hour (as at July 2017).


The Living Wage Foundation and HMRC are great sources of information on wages.


Show me - Living Wage Foundation

Show me - HMRC The national minimum wage and living wage

Confirm that your potential or new employee has the legal right to work in the UK. 


You may have to do other employment checks as well. 


Show me - Check if someone can work in the UK
_items.title: Confirm the employee's legal right to work in the UK

_items.body:
Apply for a DBS check (formerly known as a CRB check) if you work in a field that requires it.


For example, if you work with vulnerable people or security services. 


Show me - DBS checks
_items.title: Obtain security clearances if needed
Get employment insurance
_items.body:
You need employers’ liability insurance as soon as you become an employer. 


Show me - HMRC employers' liability insurance

_items.title: Provide a written statement of employment
_items.body:
Provide your new employee with these written documents:

  • A job description
  • Details of the job
  • Working terms and conditions


You must give your employee a written statement of employment if you’re employing someone for more than one month. 


Show me - Employment particulars written statement

_items.title: Register as an employer
_items.body:
Tell HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) that you are now an employer by registering yourself as an employer. You can do this up to four weeks before you start to pay new staff. 


Show me - Register as an employer

title: The responsibilities of an employer

body: Select three approaches to recruiting mentors and advisers.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Most successful business leaders are happy to give back to promising entrepreneurs who make the most of their time with focused, well researched questions and people who show willingness to take their advice on board.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


Most successful business leaders are happy to give back to promising entrepreneurs who make the most of their time with focused, well researched questions and people who show willingness to take their advice on board.

_items.text: Approach industry leaders who you particularly admire at conferences or other networking events.
Contact leaders whose blogs or articles you have read and found particularly helpful.
Offer advisers large proportions of your equity for giving you ad hoc advice.
Contact organisations and local business forums and ask if they know anyone with the particular experience and attributes you are looking for.

title: Mentors and advisers

body: Rank the steps to hiring the right candidates.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


What normally happens is write the job description, get the word out, interview with multiple colleagues, sell the role to your dream candidate and uphold your responsibilities as an employer.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Write the job description, get the word out, interview with multiple colleagues, sell the role to your dream candidate and uphold your responsibilities as an employer.

_items.text: Write a detailed job description
Put the word out, especially through your networks
Select the right candidate through interviews with multiple team members
Sell the role to the right candidate, including the non-financial benefits
Uphold your legal responsibilities as an employer

cancelButtonAriaLabel: This button cancels the current selected option
title: Hire the right candidates

body:
Out of all the options below, one of them is NOT an employer's legal requirement.


Which is the odd one out?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Health checks are not part of an employer's legal responsibilities - but the others are.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Health checks are not part of an employer's legal responsibilities - but the others are.

_items.text: Pay employees the minimum wage.
Check up on employee's health history.
Get employee's liability insurance.
Register with HMRC as an employer.
Get a security check if the role is with vulnerable people.
Check the employee's right to work in the UK.
Send employees a statement of employment within one month of starting.

title: Be a compliant employer

body:
To build your team, you can start with mentors and advisers. 


From there you can use the four step process to plan, source, screen and hire the right people for your team. 


Finally, you can ensure your team is well looked after and keep things in order by upholding your six legal responsibilities as an employer.
displayTitle: Get the right people for the right job!
title: How can I build a winning team? Let's wrap it up

body:
Your idea started life as something in your head, which was then turned into some models on paper, and then turned into a clearly explained idea that customers and investors can give you early feedback on. 


Now let's look at how to get your idea and product through the planning stage.


Let's see how to:

  • Check if your idea is worth acting on or holding out for a better one
  • Plan a detailed and coherent proposition to customers by creating a pitch video, basic website and brochure
  • Draft a business plan to explain your offer to business partners and co-founders
title: Here's how

body:
If this idea is worthwhile then you should be able to answer Yes to the following questions.


If you're unsure, don't hesitate to go through the idea generation and sorting process, to find a concept you strongly believe could work for you.


Your time and effort is valuable so it is best to spot any fatal flaws while you are still working on paper.


Tick off the following that are applicable to you.


Big hint: you should be ticking these all off, so be sure to include them in your planning process!

_items.title: Can I clearly explain the problem I'm trying to solve for my customer?
Can I list the main assumptions behind my business model?
Can I say I've explored the different business models, using the canvas, and chosen the one I think is best?

title: Is this idea worth investigating?

_media._source: C2M2V1 from DBAVideo on Vimeo.

body:
Here is a founders' story from Emma at Silkfred.


Silkfred is a platform hosting independent fashion brands.


Emma talks about how she decided to make the jump.
title: Founders' stories: Emma at Silkfred

displayTitle: Founders' stories: Josh at Night Zookeeper
body:
Here is a founders Story from Josh, the founder of Night Zookeeper.


Night Zookeeper is an interactive literacy tool for children.


Josh talks about how he decided to make the jump, too.
title: Founders' stories: Josh at Night Zookeeper

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222495881" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body:
A great way to check that your offering is clear and is going to be exciting for customers is to plan backwards. 


By making a set of promotional materials that explains to customers what you are offering, you will start to discover the gaps in your concept.  


This is when you start to think like your customers. 


Three ideal formats for your customer proposition are:

  • A pitch video
  • A basic website with key information

  • A product brochure


So, what should these materials aim to do? 


If your proposition is truly compelling, your materials should generate:

  • Awareness
  • Interest
  • Desire
  • Action
displayTitle: Plan a solid offer for customers
title: Plan a solid offer for customers

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222497078" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe><iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222497078" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

body:
A 2 to 3 minute video brings your value proposition to life. 


You can share it on your homepage, in an e-brochure, or at pitches.


There are many different formats and styles to pitch videos.

Ultimately, it is all about what will engage your customers the most.
title: Make a pitch video

body: Tim Yusupov at Zooza provides his take on a pitch video.
title: A pitch video example

body: Wordpress provides many free templates for websites and landing pages, such as this theme called Construction Website.
title: Wordpress example

body:
Customers will expect you to have at least a website or landing page online that explains what your idea is, who you are, and how to contact you. They will use it to also keep themselves updated on your developments.


The good news is that you don't need any technical skills or too much money to do this. There are lots of free web services for building websites and landing pages.


Show me - Wordpress


When we talk about landing pages, it could be something as simple a web page with a short description and a newsletter sign-up option.
displayTitle: A simple landing page or website
title: A simple landing page or website

body:
Werner Vogels, CTO of Amazon, blogged about the value of making promotional materials for a product that did not yet exist. 


This is a valuable exercise that helps you to work out your business plans.

_items.body:
Your press release should describe in a simple way what the product does and why it exists. What are the features and benefits? 


It should clarify how the world will see the product, not just how you think about it.
_items.title: Write a press release

_items.body:
Put yourself in the shoes of someone reading the press release or using the product and consider all the questions that they may come up with.


This should help you anticipate some frequently asked questions (FAQ) to help you figure out the issues and resistance that potential customers may have with your idea or product.
_items.title: Create an FAQ
Create a customer journey
_items.body:
Describe in precise detail the customer experience for different things they might do with the product, for example registering for the newsletter or buying the product. 


For products with a user interface, build mock-ups of each screen that the customer sees, highlighting the options.


For web services, write use cases, including code snippets, to describe the ways you imagine customers will use the product. 


The goal here is to tell stories about how customers are solving their problems using your product.

title: Create promotional materials

displayTitle: Plan a solid offer for business partners
body:
Here are some suggested sections for your business plan. 


These are designed  to win over prospective colleagues and investors.

_items.body:
• Who should be on our management team?

  • What is the best organisational structure for this business?
_items.title: Executive summary

_items.body: • What products will our customers want to buy?
_items.title: Details of the problem and solution

_items.body: • How will we make money?
_items.title: Your business model
Your competitive advantage
_items.body: • How will we make money?

_items.title: Marketing and sales strategy
_items.body:
• Which customers should we target?
  • What products will our customers want to buy?

  • How should we communicate with our customers?

  • How can we protect our brand?

  • Which things should our company do, and which things should our partners and suppliers do?

• Who are our competitors?

  • What makes us better?

  • How will we know when to change course?
_items.title: Competitor analysis
Management team required
_items.body:
• Who are our competitors?

  • How are we better?

  • How will we know when to change course?

• Who should be on our management team?

  • What is the best organisational structure for this business?
_items.title: Financial projections and key metrics
Current status, accomplishments, timelines and use of funds
_items.body:
• What have we achieved so far?
  • Whose investment capital will help us, and whose might hurt us?

title: Plan a solid offer for business partners

body: Of the four questions below, select three that are helpful when deciding whether to take an idea forward.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


You can't be 100% sure an idea works until you try it but the other questions could help you weed out a weak idea.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


You can't be 100% sure an idea works until you try it but the other questions could help you weed out a weak idea.

_items.text: Can you clearly explain the customer's problem?
Can you clearly list the assumptions behind your business model?
Have you explored different business models and chosen the one you think will work best?
Are you 100% sure it will work?

title: Clarify your idea

body:
Your pitch video, website and brochure can help you to plan your offer for customers in detail. 


They are also helpful to win over your first customers. 


Of the four options below, which of them is NOT a core aim of customer materials?

_feedback.correct:
Well done! 


Customer materials should generate awareness, interest, desire and action.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Customer materials should generate awareness, interest, desire and action.

_items.text: Grab your customers attention so they know you exist
Make the customers desire your solution
Make customers believe you have been running for years and years
Convince customers that you understand their problem and you can solve it

title: Customer materials

body: Of the four options below, which two statements about business plans are FALSE?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Business plans should be dynamic and customised documents.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Business plans should be dynamic and customised documents.

_items.text: They should follow a set best practice structure
They should be set in stone. Once you write it, you need to stick to it
They will be constantly changing
They could be tailored for a changing audience

title: Business plans

body:
You should now be clear about how to plan your customer offer in detail, and be confident in creating promotional materials that will also help you to get early feedback from customers. 


You are also now ready to start drafting a business plan which should convince investors and future co-founders that your idea is likely to work. 


Now you are well on your way to launching your product!
title: Make a detailed plan. Let's wrap it up

body:
The best source of funding is always from selling your product - that way you don't owe anyone anything!


For that reason, the less you can spend before you start to bring in sales, the better. 


You need to be creative and bold to get a lot done on  a shoestring. But you will be positively surprised by how much can be done for free (or very little).


To get by, you may want to find out about -

  • What freebies and discounts you might be eligible for 
  • How you could get your first pot of money
  • What is important to investors when they think about investing
title: Text Title

body:
There is a wealth of support available for entrepreneurs. 


Here are some potential shortcuts you might consider researching.

_items.body:
Look for accelerators.


These are funded programmes that are located all around the country, offering mentoring, free office space and sometimes money to startups who the accelerators think look promising.
_items.title: Office space

_items.body:
Have you looked on Freecycle for people giving things away? 


Show me - Freecycle


A timely post on Facebook could unearth friends with spare chairs, printers and laptops lying around.


Do you have any corporate partners who just happen to  be upgrading their old stock?
_items.title: Office furniture and supplies

_items.body:
Local libraries and universities sometimes offer free business advice to startups. 


Legal firms often do pro bono work for startups in the hope they will become clients down the line. Perhaps you can help them in return? Fixing their website? Tutoring their kids? Helping out a charity they are passionate about?


In any case, it is always worth asking, and for the cost of a coffee and cake, it could make all the difference.
_items.title: Advice

_items.body:
The internet is full of free and low cost platforms and templates which you only need to customise  to make them ready for launch. 


Whether you are launching a marketplace, a crowdfunding website, an online shop or a community, check there isn't a ready made template before paying to have your own built.
_items.title: Simple websites

title: Bootstrapping

body:
There is no doubt that the best source of funding is from paying customers. That said, you might well need money to get to that point. 


Here's a brief summary of the main types of funding available, and then we will outline what type of funding you might go for at each stage of your business' development.

_items.body:
Usually from charities or the government.


Pros - This is 'free money' you don't have to pay back. 


Cons - There may be strict rules on how you can spend it, and a responsibility to submit detailed reports often.
_items.title: Grants

_items.body:
This could be money from banks or crowdfunding sources. 


Pros - Easy to get.


Cons -  It must be repaid (usually with interest) at a specific time and often requires some kind of security deposit from the founder or the business.
_items.title: Debt
Equity
_items.body:
Funding in return for shares in your company. 


Traditionally from Business Angels and professional Venture Capital funds, but increasingly from new sources on platforms like PeopleFundIt or Crowdcube. 


Show me - Peoplefundit

Show me - Crowdcube


Pros - Often comes with expertise and mentoring. 


Cons -  These providers want the opportunity to get a return on their investment, so you will need to plan how you will eventually give them their money back, for example, by selling the business. 


Other hybrid models include Convertible Instruments which start as a loan and convert into equity when the business reaches an agreed milestone.

title: Different types of early funding

body: As a business grows through different phases, the types of funding they might typically need changes, too.

_items.body:
This might typically be up to £50,000 and may come in the form of grants or loans from family, friends or private investors.


It could be that the entrepreneur themselves puts in the seed funding from their own savings or from the sale of an asset.
_items.title: Pre-seed
Seed
_items.body:
This might typically be up to £200,000.


It might come from specialist Venture Capitalists with seed funds, or private investors who would be looking for equity in return for their investment.

This would typically be up to £2 million and come from Venture Capitalists (Investors) working alone or in groups. 


They would request equity, usually in the form of shares in exchange for the investment.
_items.title: Startup

_items.body:
This would typically be for up to £5 million.


It would come from mainstream Venture Capital firms or banks.


They would be looking for equity or debt in exchange for their investment.
_items.title: Scale-up / Growth

title: Types of growth funds

displayTitle: Founders' stories: Raising your first pot of money
body: Alex Siljanovski, a Founder linked to the UCL Ideas Hub, shares his experiences of raising his first pot of money.

_incorrect.body: Incorrect answer, click continue to try again
_incorrect.title: Incorrect

title: Founders' stories: Raising your first pot of money

displayTitle: What do funders usually look for?
body: Here are some of the key criteria investors take into account when entrepreneurs come to them looking for money.

_items.title: Quality of the team
_items.body: Does the team have the skills, experience, networks and passion to execute on their plan?

_items.title: The scale of the opportunity
_items.body: Is this a market stall or a multinational opportunity?
What do you have that is valuable, rare, difficult to imitate or difficult to substitute? This is known as VRIS.
_items.title: The potential to stay ahead of competition

_items.body:
Momentum or traction?


Are you able to demonstrate that the team has made tangible, disciplined progress towards the reduction of key risks?
_items.title: Evidence of success

title: What do funders usually look for?

body: Three UK startup entrepreneurs pitch to investors on the reality TV show Dragon's Den.
title: Dragon's Den: Investment in action

body:
Early stage startups should borrow as much money as possible as they need a lot of cash to get going.


Is that true of false?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


The less money you need to borrow to get going, the less money you will owe down the line.


You also get to hold on to all your equity.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


The less money you need to borrow to get going, the less money you will owe down the line.


You also get to hold on to all your equity.

_items.text: True
False

title: Bootstrapping

body: Which type of funding is best described as:

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Grant funding doesn't need to be paid back, equity funding is given in exchange for shares and debt funding is loans which need to be paid back with interest.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Grant funding doesn't need to be paid back, equity funding is given in exchange for shares, and debt funding is loans which need to be paid back with interest.

_items.text: Money that doesn't need to be paid back, but often has to be spent in very specific ways
Money from a bank, for example, that needs to be paid back with interest by a specific date
Funding which is given in exchange for a stake in the business and must be paid back in the long run

title: Funding types

displayTitle: What investors look for in a business
body:
Investors are looking for particular features that make a great business investment.


Which feature is the odd one out?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Academic record is often less important than the other criteria.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Academic record is often less important than the other criteria.

_items.text: A team who they are convinced can deliver on the vision
A strong academic record
The potential for the business to grow into a large scale operation
How hard the business would be to imitate
Any evidence of early business success

title: What investors look for in a business

body:
To launch your business on a shoestring, use as many free and low cost resources as possible. Don't be afraid to ask and be creative about what you can offer in return. 


If you need extra funding, think about the option that suits you best: equity, loan, or grant funding. There are dozens of accelerators across the UK who can help you get off the ground in exchange of equity or cash investment.


When you ask for funding, focus on the things that matter to the funder, including the quality of your team, the scalability of your business, and any early evidence of success.
title: Launch your product on a shoestring. Let's wrap it up

body:
Now that you have a clear idea of what you are offering to customers, it is time to go out and find them.


The best way to do this, is to:

  • Choose which customers to reach out to first
  • Plan your sales as a 'funnel'
  • Track key information about your sales process so you can make good decisions about what to do next
title: Text Title

body:
The team at UCL university and business incubator IDEALondon share some tips on choosing your first customers.


Show me - IDEALondon
displayTitle: Who should be your first customers?

_incorrect.body: Incorrect answer, click continue to try again
_incorrect.title: Incorrect

title: Who should be your first customers?

body:
Diffusion of Innovation is a theory that seeks to explain how, why, and at what rate new ideas and technology spread.  It identifies the types of adopters of technology or new products and services.


Which of these adopters do you think are your target market?
displayTitle: Who will be your early adopters?

_items.title: Innovators
_items.body:
People who actively seek out new products to try.


Also known as hackers who are keen to work with even partially completed products.

_items.title: Early adopters
_items.body:
Visionaries who are keen to get ahead of the herd.


They are actively looking for new products or services that can make their lives better.

The first of our mainstream customers if we are going to reach significant scale. 


These are the pragmatists who want to stick with the herd. 


They seek innovation, but don't want anything that is too threatening to their business.
_items.title: Early majority

_items.body:
Conservative buyers who need a lot of convincing to switch to new solutions.


They need to be sure they are buying into a mature and robust product or service.
_items.title: Late majority

_items.body: There are always those who will only buy on the basis of price rather than improved or enhanced capability.
_items.title: Laggards

title: Who will be your early adopters?

body:
You may have developed fantastic products and services, but ultimately you need to be able to close sales with customers.


In order to do this, you need a structured, repeatable model for acquiring customers, otherwise your growth will be limited.


There are lots of ways you can chart a customer's journey from being a stranger to being a repeat buyer. 


One of them is with the classic four stage Sales Funnel process.
displayTitle: Sales as a process: the Funnel
title: Sales as a process: the Funnel

body:
Let's look at the four steps of moving customers through the funnel:

  • Prospecting
  • Cultivating
  • Positioning
  • Closing

_items.title: Step 1: Prospecting
_items.body:
Identifying potential customers to target with our sales and marketing message. 


This could involve buying lists of prospects or professional membership lists or looking for lists of companies on the Companies House website who might need your product.


You could generate lists of prospects from social networks or online communities. 


If you are selling straight to the public rather than another company, you might target advertising to specific customer segments, through online advertising platforms such as Facebook and Google Adwords.

_items.title: Step 2: Cultivating
_items.body:
You can target qualified prospects, known as the 'suspects' who have engaged with initial marketing outreach. 


They might have been referred to you from another customer or reached out to directly (for example at exhibitions or events). 


In this phase, seek to confirm that your business can solve their problem.


This phase might happen in a meeting or a phone call, but it could also happen without your intervention, possibly through a customer looking up your website and reading your marketing materials.
This is where we demonstrate how our solution meets the stated needs of the customer, and why it does this better than your competitors.
_items.title: Step 3: Positioning
Step 4: Closing
_items.body: The conversion of a prospect to a customer.

title: Moving customers through the funnel

body:
As you manage multiple customers through multiple steps of the sales journey, it is important to stay organised.


A dashboard is a good way for you to decide what data to track and how to present it. 


This is so you can get an instant snapshot of how you are doing with sales and where you need to focus your efforts.

_media._source: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/222497985" width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

title: Dashboards: What should you measure?

body:
Metrics should help you to make decisions. They are closely linked to revenue and profit. 


For example, the number of active users, user engagement or customer acquisition costs (and ultimately revenues and profit).


Other metrics might be tempting because they are easier to grow and make you feel good! 


For example, registered users, app downloads, and raw page views. These are called vanity metrics. 


Good metrics not only help you to stay focused, they give you an insight into whether customers are responding well to your offer and whether your product needs changing.  


Good metrics should be:

_items.title:
Actionable

What will you do differently based on this information?

Comparative

Can I compare it against performance in an equivalent time period, for example, this time last year?

Understandable

Are these clear enough so that I could have a conversation about them with everyone on the team, from interns to investors?

title: Good metrics vs vanity metrics

body:
When should you start selling? 


Choose two of the following three options.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Getting customer feedback and sign-ups from early innovators as soon as possible is the best place to start. Don't wait for perfection.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


The sooner you can get feedback from real customers, the better.

_items.text: When your product is perfect
Once you have customer facing materials even if you don't have a product yet
When you have a basic prototype

title: When to start selling

body: Place the steps of the sales process into the correct order.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


The sales process goes from Prospecting to Cultivating, Positioning and Closing

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


The sales process goes from  prospecting to cultivating, positioning and closing.

_items.text: Prospecting: Identifying potential customers to target with sales and marketing message
Positioning: Checking that we understand the prospect's problem, for example through meetings. Explaining to prospective customers how our solution solves their problem
Cultivating: Explaining to prospective customers how our solution solves their problem
Closing: Converting a prospect into a customer and achieving a sale

cancelButtonAriaLabel: This button cancels the current selected option
title: The sales process

body: Classify the following metrics as actionable metrics or vanity metrics.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Good metrics are actionable, comparative, and understandable.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Good metrics are actionable, comparative, and understandable.

_items.text: Number of visitors to a landing page
Number of sales from a trade show
Number of pre-orders from the landing page
Number of calls made

title: Designing good metrics

body:
Start with customers who are actively searching for a solution to a problem that you can help them with. You know that innovators will be the best people to win over first. 


You also know how to set up a repeatable sales process as a funnel. Move customers through the funnel by prospecting, cultivating, positioning and closing leads. 


Finally, you know how to gather and analyse your sales data by choosing meaningful metrics that show you are moving towards increased revenues (rather than falling into the trap of tracking vanity metrics).
title: Winning your first customers. Let's wrap it up

body:
There are many things you need to do to make your business official. 


Let's look at how to:

  • Decide on co-founder share allocations
  • Register your company legally in a form that is right for you 
  • Fulfil your legal responsibilities as a company director
title: Text Title

body:
This can be an awkward conversation, so it is best to do it early. 


Sorting out this conversation will put you in good stead for when you have to face bigger hurdles, which will inevitably arrive.

_incorrect.body: Incorrect answer, click continue to try again
_incorrect.title: Incorrect

title: Divide equity between co-founders

body:
Although you can start selling your product without being a registered business, it is often best to register early.


Registering your business before selling your product will be of great benefit to you.  For example, it will formally identify any personal liabilities and project more credibility to customers and business partners.


All you need to register the business are the names of all shareholders, an official address where you can receive mail, £15, and a unique company name. You can do this on the Companies House website.


Show me - Companies House


As part of registering, you will need to draft up a company rule book called the articles of memorandum. This can be adapted from a standard template.


The articles could include clauses such as who owns which shares, and any conditions on investment locked into the business in case someone leaves the business or doesn't deliver on their promises.


The articles aren't set in stone and you can change them as new investors come on board.
displayTitle: When and how to register your business
title: When and how to register your business

body: You will also need to decide what structure the company should have.

_items.title: Sole trader
_items.body:
A single person operating as a business. 


It’s simpler to set up as a sole trader, but you’re personally responsible for your business’s debts. 


You also have some accounting responsibilities.

_items.title: Limited company
_items.body:
A limited company has its finances separate from your personal finances, but there are more reporting and management responsibilities.


There are many versions, including:

  • For-profit business with shares
  • Company with shares
  • Non-profit business, for example, a sports club can be set up as a company that is limited by guarantee. 


Some people get help from a professional, for example an accountant, to set up a limited company. But it is possible to set it up yourself.

While all businesses hopefully make more revenue than they spend, not all are seeking to maximise profits as their ultimate goal. Social Enterprise UK defines social enterprises as:


'Businesses that trade to tackle social problems, improve communities, people’s life chances, or the environment. They make their money from selling goods and services in the open market, but they reinvest their profits back into the business or the local community'.


These businesses could be:

  • Charities
  • Community interest Companies 
  • Company Limited by Guarantee
_items.title: Social enterprise
Partnerships
_items.body:
A partnership is the simplest way for two or more people to run a business together.


You share responsibility for your business’s debts. You also have accounting responsibilities.

title: Types of businesses

body: Comany directors have several legal responsibilities.

_items.title: You must act in good faith in the interest of the company
_items.body: For example,  you must not pursue a course of action that might benefit you personally (or others) at the expense of the company.

_items.title: You are legally responsible for the actions of a company
_items.body: Directors are responsible under law for the actions of the company and in some circumstances may be liable to losses arising from their actions (ignorance is no defence!).
This should include the preparation of annual statements of accounts for Companies House.
_items.title: You must ensure the keeping of adequate accounting records
You must ensure that the company does not trade while insolvent
_items.body: You could face serious consequences including bans from opening companies in the future.

title: Being a company director

body: Which two of the four statements are false?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


You can change articles of memorandum as shareholders join and leave the team.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


You can change articles of memorandum as shareholders join and leave the team.

_items.text: All you need to register a company is £15, the names of the directors, a mailing address and a unique company name
Articles of association are a rulebook for founders and investors about who owns which shares, and how that might change at future milestones
Articles of association are set in stone - you cannot change them
When you register you need to choose what kind of business you want to be

title: Register your company

body: Is the following statement true or false?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that? 


Although it might feel awkward, it is important to sort out founder equity early to avoid conflict down the line.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


Although it might feel awkward, it is important to sort out founder equity early to avoid conflict down the line.

_items.text:
Deciding on equity early on is not important.
It is recommended to wait until you have investors to discuss it properly.

title: Divide equity between founders

body: Directors have many legal responsibilities.  Which of the following is the odd one out?

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure? 


It is often the responsibility of a director to decide on CEO salaries, but not always.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 


It is often the responsibility of a director to decide on CEO salaries, but not always

_items.text: Acting in the best interest of the company
Submitting annual accounts to Companies House
Making sure the company doesn't trade while insolvent
Ensuring the CEO's remuneration is greater than the market average
Making sure the company operates within the law

title: Directors responsibilities

body: Now you know how to decide on share allocation with your co-founders, how to register with Companies House and know your responsibilities as a director.
title: Summary
